text:
yeah its getting a balance between price and size matched, too early and you reach market capacity with minimal matched, too late and the price has already gone. There is a big player who gets involved bang on 2 minutes, most are a lot more subtle and getting the money down.

I know a few then factor in market technicals to try and optimise their execution but its certainly a dark art, it really doesn't take much money to move the price.

• Get historical form data and odds, for developing a model.
• Getting up-to-date data, feeding that into a model, lining up that data with Betfair markets/selections, then placing bets?

text:
Depends, some have entire teams on each individual part, infra/data/model/execution and some are one man bands doing it all themselves and not far off syndicate levels. I personally think experience is the most important factor in how long something like this would take.

But tbh play to your strengths, if you aren't an expert in fundamental modelling do you really want to try and compete with those that are?

text:
Would this be a viable strategy?
1. Use ML or other method to determine fixtures to predict high likelihood of one or both teams scoring.
2. If 0-0 at half time, lay the draw.
3. Trade out as soon as the first goal is scored.

elements.text: Would this be a viable strategy?
Use ML or other method to determine fixtures to predict high likelihood of one or both teams scoring.
If 0-0 at half time, lay the draw.
Trade out as soon as the first goal is scored.

text: The tough part is step 1. Figuring out that goals are more likely than the market implies. If you can do that, there are certainly ways to profit off such a prediction

elements.text: The tough part is step 1. Figuring out that goals are more likely than the market implies. If you can do that, there are certainly ways to profit off such a prediction

text: For a strategy to be profitable you need to take +EV bets. Why do you believe that laying 0-0 half time for these matches (at any price?) is a +EV bet? Why do you believe that trading out after the first goal is a +EV bet?

elements.text: For a strategy to be profitable you need to take +EV bets. Why do you believe that laying 0-0 half time for these matches (at any price?) is a +EV bet? Why do you believe that trading out after the first goal is a +EV bet?

text: i assume something is missing in those steps. Step one isnt used at all in your actual bet-placing

elements.text: i assume something is missing in those steps. Step one isnt used at all in your actual bet-placing

text: <@U02BG9NUJF6> the flaw is thinking of something you believe is likely/unlikely and assuming nobody else has seen it. <@U01A3B4SBDZ> has nailed it. Step one needs to produce a probability, steps 2 and 3 need to get a better price than your estimate of that probability suggests. All your approach seems to be doing is vastly reducing the number of games you'll consider betting on.

elements.text: the flaw is thinking of something you believe is likely/unlikely and assuming nobody else has seen it.

text: In other words, why isn’t this +EV compared to what everyone else is doing? No one knows the true probabilities…

elements.text: In other words, why isn’t this +EV compared to what everyone else is doing? No one knows the true probabilities…

text: The issue is this: what do you mean by "likely" ? You need to get a probability from that. Once you have a probability estimate you can use that to assess +/- EV. Now if you want to model the same thing only on games that are 0-0 at half time, then do that but the principle is the same. You need to decide what you mean by likely. You see this kind of stuff from people selling ebooks and "systems" where you won't hear or see the word "value" anywhere.

elements.text: The issue is this: what do you mean by "likely" ? You need to get a probability from that. Once you have a probability estimate you can use that to assess +/- EV. Now if you want to model the same thing only on games that are 0-0 at half time, then do that but the principle is the same. You need to decide what you mean by likely. You see this kind of stuff from people selling ebooks and "systems" where you won't hear or see the word "value" anywhere.

text: Consider this. You determine a "likely" target game but with no probability estimate. You can lay the draw at half time (at 0-0) for 2.2 - is that value? You have another game on your target list but you can only lay this one at 1.8 . None, either or both of these prices could be +EV but without that magic number how can you tell?

elements.text: Consider this. You determine a "likely" target game but with no probability estimate. You can lay the draw at half time (at 0-0) for 2.2 - is that value? You have another game on your target list but you can only lay this one at 1.8 . None, either or both of these prices could be +EV but without that magic number how can you tell?

text: <@U02BG9NUJF6> yes nobody knows the precise probability. But it's your job to get as close as you can. Take your two high scoring teams, 0-0 in an action packed game and 15mins left. What price would you take on the draw? Or the opposite, 2 hapless teams and both need a draw to survive relegation, what price then? It's just buying and selling Vanush, look for the good deals and avoid being ripped off.

elements.text: yes nobody knows the precise probability. But it's your job to get as close as you can. Take your two high scoring teams, 0-0 in an action packed game and 15mins left. text:
<@U02BG9NUJF6> I am a beginner in ML for about 6 months. From my experience, you have to lower your expectations of what you can achieve in a short time.

Everything you're thinking about doing is already being done, so your job is to find a unique approach within what is already being done. This will only come from experimenting, imo.

What I have found to work is nothing at all like I thought it would be when I started and even what is "working" is still losing money. Only, it's not losing as bad as it started out and it's getting better every day as I discover what is right and wrong.

Something else you will need to learn about is execution. This is what the big boys focus on most of the time anyway. I don't quite fully understand what it means and I suspect my results are more dependent on this than I currently realise. E.g. reducing commission which has eroded every edge I have discovered, and getting matched on bets I know are value but having to beat others to the punch.

elements.text:
I am a beginner in ML for about 6 months. From my experience, you have to lower your expectations of what you can achieve in a short time.

Everything you're thinking about doing is already being done, so your job is to find a unique approach within what is already being done. This will only come from experimenting, imo.

What I have found to work is nothing at all like I thought it would be when I started and even what is "working" is still losing money. Only, it's not losing as bad as it started out and it's getting better every day as I discover what is right and wrong.

Something else you will need to learn about is execution. This is what the big boys focus on most of the time anyway. I don't quite fully understand what it means and I suspect my results are more dependent on this than I currently realise. E.g. reducing commission which has eroded every edge I have discovered, and getting matched on bets I know are value but having to beat others to the punch.
